# Banking System Soundness

Despite increased uncertainty in the global economy and financial markets, the Hong Kong banking system remained resilient in 2018. The effectiveness of liquidity and credit risk management systems at authorized institutions continued to be a key regulatory focus for the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) throughout the year. Given the ongoing rise in cyber threats and the broader adoption of financial technology by the banking sector, the HKMA strengthened its oversight of authorized institutions’ technology risk management and business continuity capabilities. In May, the HKMA issued a revised guideline on the authorization of virtual banks and began processing applications for virtual bank authorization. In terms of conduct regulation, the HKMA took further measures to strengthen oversight of authorized institutions’ sales practices for investment and insurance products, promote accessible banking services for people with disabilities, and foster a customer-centric corporate culture.

As financial crimes become increasingly complex and globalized, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to enhance Hong Kong’s capabilities in combating money laundering and terrorist financing through the adoption of new technologies and a risk-based approach. The HKMA has made significant progress in implementing international regulatory standards in Hong Kong, including those related to capital adequacy, disclosure, liquidity, and large exposure limits. Furthermore, the HKMA has strengthened communication with the banking sector to ensure an appropriate balance between regulatory effectiveness and market development.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to ensure Hong Kong has a credible resolution framework for authorized institutions, including the introduction of rules on minimum loss-absorbing capacity requirements to overcome a key obstacle to their orderly resolution.

# Objectives

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s primary goal is to foster the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this requires establishing and maintaining a financial system that is highly resilient and capable of providing the essential financial services needed by the Hong Kong economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the banking system through their operational practices, or even, in extreme cases, through disorderly collapse. As the regulatory authority, the Financial Secretary plays a key role in safeguarding financial stability by ensuring banks have the capacity to withstand shocks, respond to crises, and restore normal functioning, ultimately helping to prevent bank failures. The Financial Secretary is responsible for the prudential supervision of banks and the authorization of licensed banks, restricted licensed banks, and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively referred to as “authorized institutions”). The Financial Secretary also oversees the designation and regulation of certain financial market infrastructures.

However, the Financial Secretary cannot guarantee a risk-free financial system, nor is Hong Kong’s prudential regulatory regime designed to eliminate all risk. As one of the resolution authorities, the Financial Secretary strives to ensure that, should an authorized institution become unsustainable, its failure can be managed in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution framework, under which the Financial Secretary serves as the resolution authority for certain financial institutions, including authorized institutions. To build a smoothly functioning resolution framework, it is essential to establish resolution legislation and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the resolvability of authorized institutions, and develop the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s operational capacity to resolve non-viable authorized institutions. To effectively carry out this work, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority needs to adopt approaches consistent with international standards.

# 2018: Year in Review

# Overview of Regulatory Work

In 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) conducted 187 off-site reviews covering a wide range of areas, including the CAMEL ratings of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations, risk management, and their business strategies for addressing financial technology developments. To further strengthen risk governance, the HKMA held 27 meetings with the boards of directors or board committees of authorized institutions and monitored their implementation of corporate governance guidelines. In addition, the HKMA held 28 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site reviews, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to conduct regular on-site inspections, complemented by thematic assessments to evaluate areas considered higher risk. During the year, the HKMA carried out a total of 392 on-site inspections and thematic assessments, with a primary focus on credit risk management. Other key areas of emphasis included technology risk and operational risk management, as well as measures to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA also increased the number of on-site inspections and thematic assessments relating to liquidity and market risk management, and the implementation of the Basel capital adequacy framework. Dedicated review teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions’ businesses involving securities, investment products, insurance, and mandatory provident fund (MPF) matters.

Table 1 presents an overview of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s supervisory work in 2018.

# Credit Risk Supervision

# Credit growth and asset quality.

Credit growth slowed in 2018, with total loans increasing by 4.4% for the year, compared to a 16.1% increase in 2017 (Table 2). Trade financing decreased by 7.6% in 2018. This slowdown in lending was primarily attributable to increasing uncertainty in the global economic and trade environment, resulting in a contraction of credit demand.

Increase in Loans and Advances

Loans to the mainland increased by 1.4% to HK$424.9 billion at the end of 2018, a slower pace than the growth seen in 2017 (Table 3).

Table 3: Growth of Loans to Mainland China

The asset quality of financial institutions remained stable in 2018. The non-performing loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.56% at the end of 2017 to 0.50% at the end of 2018, significantly below the long-term average of 2.1% since 2000. During the same period, the overall banking sector’s non-performing loan ratio fell from 0.68% to 0.55%. Regarding Mainland loans, the non-performing loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.75% to 0.63% in 2018, while the corresponding ratio for the overall banking sector also decreased from 0.67% the previous year to 0.54%.

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will strengthen its regulatory oversight to ensure that authorized institutions continue to adopt prudent credit risk management practices. In particular, the HKMA will proactively enhance its understanding of the background and structure of large enterprises, thereby improving the monitoring of corporate credit risk. Furthermore, the HKMA will conduct thematic assessments focusing on key credit risk management monitoring measures, including loan approval criteria and risk management for large corporate loans, loan classification and provisioning systems, credit risk governance frameworks, risk management for loans to property developers, and loans secured by insurance policies.

# Property Mortgage Loan

Residential property prices reached a historical high in July 2018 but showed signs of easing in the second half of the year. The eight rounds of countercyclical macroprudential measures introduced by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) since October 2009 have enhanced the Hong Kong banking system’s ability to withstand a potential downturn in the local property market. The average mortgage loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgages fell from 64% in September 2009, before the first round of countercyclical measures, to 46% in December 2018. The average debt service-to-income ratio also fell from 41% in August 2010, when the ratio cap was first introduced, to 34% in December 2018 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Average Loan-to-Value Ratio and Repayment-to-Income Ratio for Newly Constructed Residential Mortgages

# Operational and Technology Risk Oversight

The technology risks facing the banking sector remain relatively high. In 2016, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Cybersecurity Assessment Framework. The first phase covered 30 authorized institutions, including all major banks, which have completed a three-stage assessment process: self-assessment of risk levels, maturity assessment, and, where applicable, cyber attack simulation exercises guided by risk intelligence. These assessments have helped institutions identify areas for improvement and take corrective actions to strengthen their cybersecurity defenses. Meanwhile, the HKMA has established a timetable for the second and third phases, which will encompass the remaining authorized institutions. This year, the HKMA will conduct on-site reviews, focusing on cybersecurity controls, outsourcing arrangements, and information technology governance.

# Intelligent Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with the banking sector on the seven measures announced in September 2017 to promote smart banking and foster the development of financial technology in Hong Kong. On the regulatory front, the HKMA issued a revised version of the “Guidelines on the Authorization of Virtual Banks” in May. Furthermore, under the “Banking Facilitation” initiative, the HKMA has simplified regulatory requirements relating to remote account opening, online loans, and online wealth management. These streamlined requirements help banks provide an improved online banking experience. In September, the scope of the “Banking Facilitation” initiative was expanded to encourage the adoption of regulatory technology (Regtech) by banks, with three new areas of focus: technology for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, Regtech for prudent risk management and compliance, and machine-readable regulatory requirements.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Deputy Governor Ryan Wong delivered a speech titled “Financial Compliance Technology in the New Era of Smart Banking” at the Hong Kong Bankers’ Summit 2018, hosted by the Hong Kong Bankers’ Association.

# Regulatory Oversight of Liquidity and Market Risk

As the U.S. monetary policy continues to normalize, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has strengthened its regulation of liquidity risk to ensure that authorized institutions prudently and effectively manage their liquidity risks. During the year, the HKMA conducted a thematic review to assess the preparedness of authorized institutions for potential tightening of dollar liquidity and their ability to conduct internal liquidity stress tests. In addition, the HKMA monitored compliance by authorized institutions with the “Net Stable Funding Ratio” requirements that took effect in January.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) reviewed the market risk management of authorized institutions’ bond portfolios and conducted a targeted on-site review of margin and risk mitigation standards for non-centrally cleared over-the-counter derivatives, as well as the Global Foreign Exchange Code, to assess authorized institutions’ compliance with new international standards in their treasury operations.

# Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

The Hong Kong government’s “Risk Assessment Report on Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing,” published in April, highlighted that Hong Kong’s banking system faces significant money laundering threats, similar to other international financial centers. This reflects the increasing globalization and complexity of financial services. These threats originate primarily from overseas activities, though local criminal activity also contributes. These overseas activities include illicit proceeds from foreign corruption, fraud committed by transnational criminal organizations, tax evasion, and risks related to sanctions, stemming from Hong Kong’s position as a key payment and trade hub. With the assistance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the government has formulated a policy statement on combating money laundering and terrorist financing, outlining its response to these threats. The objective is to strengthen the system’s ability to counter these illicit activities while also attracting and facilitating legitimate business.

The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Financial Institutions) (Amendment) Ordinance 2018 came into effect on March 1, introducing amendments that provide flexibility in customer due diligence to accommodate the development of technology-enabled customer onboarding by authorized institutions. The new legislation also expands its scope, requiring lawyers, accountants, real estate agents, and trust or company service providers to bear responsibility for countering money laundering and terrorist financing, thereby comprehensively strengthening the AML/CFT regime. These amendments, together with revisions to the Companies Ordinance aimed at enhancing transparency of beneficial ownership, will assist authorized institutions in their AML/CFT efforts.

To consolidate and strengthen communication with recognized institutions regarding policies and regulations for countering money laundering and terrorist financing, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) issued a new section, “Regulatory Approaches to Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing,” under its “Regulatory Policy Manual” in October. Accompanying this was a revised “Guidelines on Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Applicable to Recognized Institutions)” to align with relevant legislative amendments. These measures aim to more effectively implement a risk-based approach and reduce challenges for recognized institutions in adopting new technologies for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing systems.

The role of information sharing is increasingly important in combating money laundering and terrorist financing. With the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB), the banking sector has actively participated in the Anti-Fraud and Anti-Money Laundering Intelligence Working Group (the Working Group) and has achieved substantial results. A review of the Working Group’s pilot scheme commenced at the end of 2018 and will be completed in early 2019.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

# Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Center

Strengthening Hong Kong’s position as an international financial center is a key responsibility of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. Seven initiatives to promote the development and application of financial technology in the banking and payment industries have made significant progress this year, most notably with the successful launch of the fast payment system, FPS.

The optimization measures for the mutual market access programs between Mainland China and Hong Kong, coupled with the development of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, have further strengthened Hong Kong’s unique position as a primary gateway to Mainland China. Hong Kong’s status as a global offshore RMB business hub has also been solidified, with robust growth in RMB financial activities.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is actively pursuing new opportunities to bolster Hong Kong’s financial competitiveness, focusing on areas such as infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centers, and the green bond market. The HKMA is also enhancing its outreach to international and mainland counterparts to promote Hong Kong’s advantages. Internationally, the HKMA takes a leading role in numerous regional and global committees, showcasing Hong Kong’s expertise and dedication to these important initiatives.

# Overview

To bolster Hong Kong’s position as Asia’s financial technology hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to implementing the seven measures announced in September 2017 to foster the development and application of fintech in the banking and payment sectors. Key progress made this year on these initiatives to promote smart banking includes:

Successfully launched the fast payment system “FPS” (轉數快), fully connecting different banks and stored value payment tools (collectively referred to as “e-wallets”).
Published the banking industry Open Application Programming Interface (Open API) framework and promoted its implementation.
Enhanced financial technology research and talent development.
Strengthened cross-border financial technology cooperation.
Revised the guidelines on the recognition of virtual banks and processed virtual bank license applications.
The upgraded “Fintech Regulatory Sandbox” (FSS 2.0) is operating smoothly.
Expanded “BankEasy” to promote the adoption of financial compliance technology by banks.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) Financial Technology Promotion Office (FFO), together with the HKMA’s banking departments, plays a vital role in implementing these measures.

With the implementation of enhanced measures for the mutual market access schemes between Mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong’s unique position as a key gateway to the Mainland market has been further strengthened. The full implementation of the “Bond Connect” scheme with simultaneous delivery versus payment (DvP) settlement, coupled with the State Council’s announcement of tax exemptions for overseas investors in China’s bond market, has significantly boosted the scheme’s efficiency and appeal. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is also collaborating closely with Mainland authorities to explore and implement various financial support measures, facilitating business and investment in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA). Hong Kong’s offshore RMB business continues to thrive, with the RMB deposit pool increasing by 6% year-on-year to RMB 657.7 billion; the average daily transaction volume of the RMB Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system reached a high of RMB 1.0101 trillion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is actively pursuing new opportunities to enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform. To promote the development of the Hong Kong bond market, the HKMA has launched the “Bond Subsidy Pilot Scheme” outlined in the Budget, providing subsidies to institutions issuing bonds in Hong Kong for the first time. It is also collaborating closely with the Government to amend legislation, expanding the scope of bond investment income eligible for tax exemption under the “Eligible Debt Instruments Scheme.” Furthermore, the HKMA is strengthening its marketing efforts to promote Hong Kong’s advantages to stakeholders in overseas and Mainland China, including organizing a number of large-scale and specialized outreach events to position Hong Kong as a leading hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate treasury centres.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) chairs multiple regional and international committees. It currently chairs the Standing Committee on Regulatory Cooperation under the Financial Stability Board, the Task Force on Regulatory and Implementation Standards under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee), and the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks Meeting (EMEAP).

The secure and efficient operation of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure lays a solid foundation for Hong Kong’s status as an international financial center. In 2018, the four RTGS systems handling interbank transactions, the Debt Securities Central Clearing System (CMU System), and the Hong Kong Trading Data Repository (Hong Kong Repository) achieved a system availability rate of 100%, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Through accounts with two central securities depositories in mainland China, the CMU System continued to facilitate the settlement of Northbound “Bond Connect” transactions and held mainland debt securities on behalf of relevant CMU System members.

To facilitate the overall security and efficiency of the retail payment industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) designated two additional retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the “Payment Ordinance”), bringing the total number of systems under HKMA supervision to six. The HKMA also regulates 16 licensed stored value facility operators, who are actively introducing new products and services to enhance customer experience and provide greater choice. Furthermore, the scope of electronic cheque and electronic bill payment services has been expanded to include cross-border transactions between Hong Kong and the entire Guangdong Province.

# 2018 Retrospective

# Hong Kong as Asia's Fintech Hub

# Advancing Smart Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced seven measures to promote smart banking in September 2017, aiming to help the banking industry advance and capitalize on the significant opportunities presented by the convergence of banking and technology. The HKMA has made good progress during the year in implementing these measures and transforming Hong Kong’s financial ecosystem.

# Sharp and quick-thinking.

Fast Transfer was successfully launched in September, enabling bank and stored-value payment tool users to make instant cross-bank transfers in Hong Kong dollars and Renminbi by simply entering the recipient’s mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 stored-value payment tool operators have joined the system, offering customers instant payment services and account linking services.

Fast Transfer has received over 2 million registrations within 3.5 months, representing 27% of Hong Kong’s population. Since its launch, the system has processed over 4.8 million transactions, involving a total value exceeding HK$104.9 billion and RMB 2.75 billion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Hong Kong Retail Payment Shared QR Code Standard and its associated mobile application, “HKQR,” in the same month. This globally pioneering application unifies multiple QR codes into a single code, enabling merchants – particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) – to accept payment schemes from different payment service providers using just one QR code, eliminating the need to display multiple codes to customers.

# Application Programming Interface

Open APIs enable banks to share their data with third-party service providers, fostering seamless integration of banking services with other industries. This allows users to access a comprehensive range of services through a single, secure system. To encourage the development and adoption of Open APIs within the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Open API Framework in July. The framework employs a risk-based approach and is being implemented in four phases. As of January 31, 2019, 20 banks had opened approximately 500 API interfaces in the first phase, providing data access to over 1,000 products and services.

# Scientific Research and Talent Development

A consortium of Hong Kong banks launched TradeConnect, a trade finance platform based on distributed ledger technology (DLT), in October, building on the results of a trade finance proof-of-concept led by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks by digitizing trade documents and automating trade finance processes. By the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined the consortium. In October, TradeConnect signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the European trade finance platform we.trade to conduct a proof-of-concept integration between the two platforms. The HKMA is also exploring opportunities to connect TradeConnect with other regions, including collaborating with the Monetary Authority of Singapore to launch the Global Trade Connectivity Network.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (left) at the Trade Connect launch ceremony.

To cultivate more fintech talent, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched an upgraded version of the “Fintech Talent Development Program” (FCAS 2.0) in January, in collaboration with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI). FCAS 2.0 features four initiatives tailored to young professionals at different career stages, and has benefited over 200 students.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (second from the left) attended the FCAS 2.0 launch ceremony with Cyberport Chairman Victor Lam (first from the left), Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute Chairman Wang Ming-xin (second from the right), and Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation CEO Albert Wong (first from the right).

# Cross-border collaboration

Following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Shenzhen Municipal People's Government Financial Development Service Office (Shenzhen Financial Office) in 2017, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has continued to strengthen its collaboration with Shenzhen in financial technology. This includes the HKMA’s sponsorship of the “Shenzhen Fintech Summer Internship Program,” which enabled 50 students to undertake six-week internships at several leading companies in Shenzhen, experiencing the local fintech ecosystem. Furthermore, the HKMA co-hosted the “Shenzhen-Hong Kong Fintech Innovation Awards” for a second time with the Shenzhen Financial Office.

Mr. Li Dazhi, Deputy Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the right), speaks with the first batch of Shenzhen Fintech summer interns.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also signed financial technology cooperation agreements in 2018 with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, the Polish Financial Supervision Authority, the Abu Dhabi International Financial Centre Financial Services Regulatory Authority, and the Central Bank of Brazil, to promote financial technology cooperation.

In August, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced the “Global Financial Innovation Network” initiative in collaboration with 11 financial regulatory authorities and related institutions. The network aims to provide innovative companies with a more effective way to engage with regulators and to foster cooperation among them on innovation-related issues.

# Virtual Bank

Introducing virtual banks will invigorate financial technology development in Hong Kong and offer customers enhanced digital banking experiences. These banks primarily target retail clients, including individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises, and will contribute to greater financial inclusion. Following public consultation, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued revised guidelines on the recognition of virtual banks in May and received around 30 applications by the end of August.

# FinTech Regulatory Sandbox

Sandbox usage has been steadily increasing throughout the year. To help establish a financial compliance technology ecosystem, the sandbox opened to related projects starting in September.

As of the end of 2018, a total of 42 financial technology or technology products had been approved for testing in the regulatory sandbox, of which 28 had completed trials and their products had subsequently been released to the market. The HKMA also received 220 inquiries through the “Fintech Regulatory Chatroom,” seeking regulatory feedback during the early stages of fintech project development. Approximately 70% of these inquiries came from technology companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Inventory Management

2018 was a difficult year for investors, as the investment landscape faced numerous risks, including tighter financial conditions resulting from continued U.S. interest rate normalization, increased trade tensions between major economies, and the rise of populism alongside heightened geopolitical risks globally. Global stock markets generally declined, and U.S. Treasury yields rose following the Federal Reserve’s four interest rate hikes. The U.S. dollar strengthened with rising U.S. interest rates. Several emerging markets, grappling with significant domestic political and economic pressures, experienced substantial currency depreciations. Despite these challenges, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$10.9 billion in 2018.

# Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar. It may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s status as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the use and investment management of the Exchange Fund, based on the powers delegated by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Asset Allocation

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee establishes and defines the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund.

(a) Preserve capital;
(b) Ensure the entire monetary base is fully supported by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;
(c) Maintain sufficient liquidity to ensure monetary and financial stability; and
(d) Subject to the foregoing (a) through (c), optimize investment returns to protect the fund’s long-term purchasing power.

These objectives fully consider the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and are reflected in its portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets, providing full backing for the monetary base in accordance with the provisions of a currency board system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in the debt and equity markets of member economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, with the aim of preserving asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is prudently and gradually diversifying a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets into a broader range of asset classes, including emerging markets and Mainland China bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging market and Mainland China bonds and equities are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The market value cap of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio is set at one-third of the Exchange Fund’s accumulated surplus plus the total of deposits from the Future Fund and Exchange Fund affiliates linked to the Long-Term Growth Portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the government for strategic purposes through the Exchange Fund. Due to its unique nature, the portfolio’s investment performance is not included in the Exchange Fund’s assessment.

# Deposits in the Foreign Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations on an irregular basis. Interest rates are generally tied to the performance of its investment portfolio, with the exception of the Future Fund. The interest rate on Future Fund deposits is dependent on the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual rate determined by the allocation between the two. At the end of 2018, the Future Fund’s assets were allocated approximately 50:50 between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio.

# Investment Process

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on strategic and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation defines the long-term asset mix reflected in the investment benchmark, representing the Fund’s target allocation to achieve its objectives. The Fund then uses this strategic allocation as a guide for tactical asset allocation, aiming to outperform the benchmark. Consequently, the actual allocation will often differ from the benchmark (the strategic allocation), and this difference is known as “tactical deviation.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and define the permissible range for tactical deviation. Portfolio managers can then select investments within this range to capitalize on short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Exchange Fund Investment Office in August, responsible for investment and related risk management. The office’s staff directly manage approximately 72% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the entire supporting portfolio and a portion of the investment portfolio, which is invested in global fixed income markets. They execute the Exchange Fund’s macro risk strategies through derivative instruments.

# External Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets internally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) engages external investment managers to oversee approximately 28% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of this engagement is to leverage the best professional investment techniques available in the market to achieve sustainable returns for the Fund, enabling it to benefit from diversified and complementary investment strategies, and to acquire valuable market knowledge and expertise.

Expenses related to engaging external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction fees, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses vary annually, primarily due to market factors.

# Risk Management and Monitoring

The investment environment is becoming increasingly complex, highlighting the importance of risk management. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established stringent control measures and investment guidelines for both internally and externally managed investment portfolios, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The HKMA has enhanced its risk assessments to align with the increasing diversification of the Exchange Fund’s investments, and employs risk management tools to assess market risk under both normal and severely adverse market conditions. The HKMA also conducts detailed investment performance attribution analysis to identify the drivers of different performance outcomes, thereby evaluating how to best leverage the investment management expertise of both internal and external managers.

# Responsible Investing

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the Stewardship Principles published by the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC). These principles aim to help investors fulfill their ownership responsibilities in Hong Kong-listed companies. Regarding the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has established internal guidelines on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, applicable to the selection, appointment, and monitoring of external fund managers. Fund managers appointed to actively manage Hong Kong equity portfolios must adhere to the Stewardship Principles when managing these investments. Overall, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA closely monitors developments in relevant ESG standards and assesses how these standards can be further integrated into its investment processes. Furthermore, to promote international cooperation on responsible investment, the HKMA has become a member of FCLTGlobal, a non-profit organization that aims to promote business and investment decisions based on a long-term orientation.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# The Financial Markets in 2018

In 2018, several risk factors previously underestimated by the market began to materialize, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of U.S. trade policy – including protectionist measures – on global trade, and geopolitical risks. These developments triggered significant volatility in international financial markets.

The escalating trade dispute between the U.S. and China caused significant concern among investors. Emerging markets and the Hong Kong stock market have experienced repeated declines since the end of January, with the Hang Seng Index falling as much as 27% from its peak that month. Major European and American stock markets also saw substantial decreases starting in the fourth quarter, with double-digit percentage losses. Overall in 2018, global stock markets generally declined, with the MSCI Global Index, covering developed market stocks, down 10.4%, and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index down 16.6%.

In the bond market, U.S. Treasury yields generally rose in 2018 due to the normalization of U.S. monetary policy. However, the bond market remained volatile throughout the year. For example, the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note increased from around 2.5% at the beginning of the year to a seven-year high of 3.2% in November, but softened to 2.7% by year-end due to investor concerns over the Sino-U.S. trade dispute and a shift towards risk-averse investments.

In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened this year, following interest rate hikes in the United States. The US Dollar Index rose 4.4%, while major currencies such as the euro and the Renminbi depreciated approximately 5% against the dollar. Additionally, currencies in some emerging markets experienced further declines due to domestic political and economic instability. For instance, the Argentine peso and the Turkish lira fell by around 50% and 30% against the dollar, respectively. In contrast, demand for safe-haven assets drove the Japanese yen up 2.7% against the dollar.

# 金管局員工

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。金管局要求其員工維持高水平的操守及道德標準，不論何時都恪守極高的個人行為及操守規範，並以金管局的最佳利益為依歸。

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with the public and the market through various channels, including the media, its website, and public education initiatives, to enhance public understanding of its policies and operations. # Stay Connected with the Public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains close communication with the media to enhance transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2018, the HKMA held 96 public media events, including 21 press conferences, 11 interviews, and 64 other public activities. Additionally, it arranged 39 media interviews and issued 462 bilingual press releases, handling numerous media inquiries daily.

To enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) key functions, the HKMA held media briefings and workshops for local and overseas media, covering a variety of topics including the linked exchange rate system, FinTech development, green finance, and infrastructure financing. In addition to enriching content on its existing YouTube channel and LinkedIn page, the HKMA launched its official Facebook page in July to further utilize social media for enhanced public communication.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (left) and the Environment Bureau’s mascot, “Big Waster,” are collaborating through social media to promote the use of new banknotes for Lunar New Year red packets.

# Public Questions

The Public Inquiry Service is an effective channel for enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s key functions and operations. In 2018, it handled a total of 9,950 inquiries, about half of which related to banking policies and regulations, consumer banking matters, and banknotes and coins, particularly the Coin Collection Scheme, banking products and services, banking guidelines and notices, the Faster Payment System (FPS), virtual banks, and the 2018 Hong Kong banknote series.

# Publications

In addition to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the Semi-annual Monetary and Financial Stability Report and four issues of the Quarterly Report in 2018, and regularly updated the Monthly Financial Data, providing the latest specialized data and analysis on Hong Kong’s currency, banking sector, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA published 13 “Insights” articles, elaborating on various topics related to its work.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 60,000 pages of information in English and both Traditional and Simplified Chinese, offering the public easy access to the latest updates from the HKMA. The website also hosts the “Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representative Offices” and the “Register of Securities Business Employees of Authorized Institutions,” maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the “Register of Licensed Stored Value Facility Operators” maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features dedicated web pages and prominent quick links to inform the public about new HKMA initiatives, such as the Faster Payment System (FPS), and important timely information, such as precautions against phone scams and the locations of cash collection vehicles during the coin collection program.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is taking the lead in promoting the adoption of open application programming interfaces (APIs) in the banking sector, having launched open APIs on its website starting in July to facilitate public access to important HKMA information. The first batch of 50 sets of open API-formatted data was successfully launched in July, covering areas frequently consulted by the public, such as statistical data on the banking system and Exchange Fund, as well as press releases and cash-in-transit schedules. The remaining 80 sets of data will be rolled out in phases before mid-2019. To further enhance public access to the latest news and information about the HKMA on its website, the HKMA is comprehensively revising the website’s design and content to make it more user-friendly. The completely redesigned website is expected to launch within 2019.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is taking the lead in fostering the development and application of open APIs.

# Public Education Initiative

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase 2. It introduces the HKMA’s work and enhances public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Centre features an exhibition hall and a library, both open to the public six days a week. The exhibition hall highlights the HKMA’s functions and the development of Hong Kong’s monetary and banking industries, with reading materials and exhibits available for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking sector, and financial affairs.

The Currency Display at the Information Centre showcases the design, security features, production process, and fascinating facts about Hong Kong banknotes and coins. The display underwent renovation in the first quarter of 2018, with the addition of interactive elements, including engaging games that make learning fun. Visitors can now explore Hong Kong currency in an enjoyable and informative way. A striking artistic Bauhinia tree has also been added, constructed from 2,018 transparent cubes made from shredded, unfit-for-circulation banknotes. This installation provides a compelling contrast to a mosaic artwork within the display, created using Hong Kong coins. The revitalized Currency Display reopened to the public on August 16th.

The Information Centre offers guided tours to visitors. This year, it hosted over 59,000 visitors and conducted more than 580 tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since opening in December 2003, the Centre has welcomed a total of over 705,000 visitors. The library, adjacent to the exhibition hall, houses a collection of over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. It also maintains the “Register of Recognized Institutions and Local Representative Offices” and the “Register of Employees Engaged in Securities Business of Recognized Institutions,” as required under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Staff

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is part of the government structure but employs staff under non-civil service terms to attract professionals with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. As a public institution, the HKMA continuously streamlines work processes to maximize efficiency and cost-effectiveness. It is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure and, as far as possible, implements new initiatives and manages rising workloads by reallocating existing staff.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is an equal opportunity employer committed to providing a workplace free from discrimination. The Authority’s equal opportunities policy applies to all aspects of employment, including recruitment, compensation and benefits, performance appraisals, promotion, transfer and training opportunities, and conduct and ethics.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority recruits, trains, and maintains a professional and highly qualified workforce to achieve its policy objectives and respond effectively to evolving job requirements. The Authority expects all staff to uphold the highest standards of integrity and ethical conduct, consistently demonstrating exemplary personal behavior and acting in its best interests.

# Organizational Structure Changes in 2018

The Exchange Fund Investment Office was established on August 1, replacing the investment and related risk management functions previously handled by the Reserve Management Department and the Risk Management and Supervision Department. The establishment of the Office highlights the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) investment capabilities, enhances its institutional image, and enables more flexible responses to market changes, supporting the continued expansion and diversification of Exchange Fund investment activities.

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Remuneration Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary determines the salaries and terms of service for Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) staff, based on recommendations from advisory committees under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee and with reference to prevailing market compensation levels and practices. The compensation package includes cash compensation and contributions to the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF), as well as a range of basic benefits. Cash compensation consists of a fixed monthly salary (basic salary) and a variable component paid annually based on employee performance.

The Financial Secretary reviews the salaries of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) staff annually, seeking advice from the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, which in turn considers recommendations from the HKMA’s oversight committee. This review takes into account the oversight committee’s assessment of the HKMA’s performance over the past year, the results of financial sector compensation surveys conducted by independent human resources firms, and other relevant factors. Individual employees with outstanding performance may also receive special salary adjustments to maintain their competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority allocates funds approved for adjusting annual fixed and variable compensation based on individual employee performance. The variable compensation system applicable to employees responsible for investments is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and compensation. Adjustments to fixed compensation and the distribution of variable compensation for employees at the level of Assistant Chief Executive and above are approved by the Financial Secretary after consulting the Governance Committee, and these employees abstain from meetings where their own compensation proposals are discussed. For employees at the level of Director and below, adjustments to fixed compensation and the distribution of variable compensation are determined by the HKMA Governor, based on authorization from the Financial Secretary and in accordance with the approved allocation for salary payments.

茲證明我已審計列載於第167至273頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2018年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

於2018年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共36,935.89億港元，金融負債共11,338.29億港元。

93%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘7%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共2,756.31億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金融 資產及金融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

審計署署長
朱乃璋

# Auditor General's Report

# Independent Auditor's Report addressed to the Financial Secretary

# Opinions

We hereby certify that we have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries (the “Group”) contained within pages 167 to 273. I consider that the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at December 31, 2018, and of their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, and have been properly prepared in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the directions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66).

# The Foundation of Opinion

I have conducted the audit in accordance with the directions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the auditing standards of the Audit Commission. My responsibilities regarding the financial statement audit are detailed in the section of this report entitled "Responsibilities of the Auditor for the Audit of Financial Statements." In accordance with these standards, I am independent of the Group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities as required. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key Audit Matters

Key audit matters are those that, in my professional judgment, are most significant to the audit of the financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2018. I addressed these matters during the audit and in forming my opinion on the financial statements as a whole, and I do not express a separate opinion on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.5, 2.6, and 40.1 to the financial statements.

As of December 31, 2018, the Group’s financial assets measured at fair value were HK$36,935.89 billion, and financial liabilities were HK$11,338.29 billion.

The fair value of 93% of these financial assets and all financial liabilities is determined by quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 inputs), or estimated using valuation techniques with inputs derived from observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The fair value of the remaining 7% of these financial assets is estimated using valuation techniques based on parameters not observable in the market (Level 3 parameters). These financial assets, totaling HKD 275.63 billion, primarily consist of unlisted investment funds.

Given the substantial amounts involved and the reliance on estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities accounted for at fair value is a key audit matter.

Audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and liabilities at fair value involve:

Understand the valuation procedures for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including associated monitoring controls.
Evaluate and test these monitoring controls, including those related to computer system applications.
Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities.
If market quotations are used, verify prices against independent sources.
If valuation method parameters are based on observable market data, assess the suitability of the method and the reasonableness of its assumptions, and verify the parameters using independent sources.
If valuation method parameters are not based on observable market data, assess the suitability of the method and the reasonableness of the assumptions and parameters.

# Valuation of investment property measured at fair value.

Please refer to Notes 2.12, 20, and 21 of the financial statements.

The Group’s investment properties are carried at fair value, totaling HK$25.321 billion as of December 31, 2018. The Group also has interests in 3 associate companies and 20 joint ventures, whose primary business is the holding of overseas investment properties, with a combined value of HK$44.336 billion. The fair value of these investment properties, whether held directly by the Group or by associate or joint venture companies, is primarily determined based on valuations from independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgment and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures for investment properties measured at fair value include:

Obtain and review valuation reports for investment properties directly held by the Group or held by associate companies or joint ventures, and verify that the fair value is determined based on the valuations stated in the relevant valuation reports; assess the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate and whether the assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Other Information

As an auditor, I am responsible for reviewing other information to assess whether it contains inconsistencies with the financial statements or information obtained during the audit, or appears to be materially misstated. Based on my work, I have no matters to report in this regard.

# Responsibilities of the Financial Commissioner and the Audit Committee within the framework of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding financial statements.

The Financial Management Officer is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance. The officer must also implement internal controls they deem necessary to ensure that the financial statements do not contain material misstatements resulting from fraud or error.

When preparing financial statements, the Financial Management Officer is responsible for assessing the group’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing any related matters if necessary, and using the going concern basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process.

# Responsibilities of Auditors in Auditing Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance regarding whether the financial statements as a whole are free of material misstatement resulting from fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards will detect any material misstatements that may exist. Misstatements may arise from fraud or error, and are considered material if they could individually or in aggregate influence the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

When auditing in accordance with the Audit Commission’s auditing standards, I will exercise professional judgment and maintain a professional skeptical attitude. I will also:

Identify and assess the risk of material misstatement in the financial statements due to fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence supporting my opinion. Because fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, false statements, or overriding of internal controls, the risk of failing to detect a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than the risk of failing to detect one resulting from error.
Understand the internal controls relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this does not involve expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal controls.
Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies adopted by management and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures.
Determine whether the use of the going concern basis of accounting by management is appropriate and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether material uncertainties exist relating to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that material uncertainties exist, I am required to draw attention to related disclosures in the financial statements in my auditor’s report, or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to issue a qualified auditor’s report. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to operate as a going concern.
Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly present the underlying transactions and events.
Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the Group audit and assume full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will report to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the audit scope and timeline, as well as significant audit findings, including any material deficiencies in internal controls identified during the audit.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, confirming that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements concerning independence, and communicate to them any relationships and other matters that are reasonably considered to affect my independence, as well as any related safeguards where applicable.

I determine which matters communicated through the audit committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee are most significant to the audit of the current financial statements, and designate these as key audit matters. I will describe these matters in my auditor’s report, unless legal or regulatory requirements prohibit disclosure, or, in extremely rare circumstances, I believe that communicating a matter would create negative consequences exceeding the public benefit.
